raw_text:
China suspends 26 power projects
 
 China has ordered a halt to construction work on 26 big power stations, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, on environmental grounds.
 
 The move is a surprising one because China is struggling to increase energy supplies for its booming economy. Last year 24 provinces suffered black outs. The State Environmental Protection Agency said the 26 projects had failed to do proper environmental assessments. Topping the list was a controversial dam on the scenic upper Yangtze River. "Construction of these projects has started without approval of the assessment of their environmental impact... they are typical illegal projects of construction first, approval next," said SEPA vice-director Pan Yue, in a statement on the agency's website.
 
 Some of the projects may be allowed to start work again with the proper permits, but others would be cancelled, he said. Altogether, the agency ordered 30 projects halted. Other projects included a petrochemicals plant and a port in Fujian. The bulk of the list was made up of new power plants, with some extensions to existing ones. The stoppages would appear to be another step in the central government's battle to control projects licensed by local officials. However, previous crackdowns have tended to focus on projects for which the government argued there was overcapacity, such as steel and cement. The government has encouraged construction of new electricity generating capacity to solve chronic energy shortages which forced many factories onto part-time working last year. In 2004, China increased its generating capacity by 12.6%, or 440,700 megawatts (MW). The biggest single project to be halted was the Xiluodi Dam project, designed to produce 12,600 MW of electricity. It is being built on the Jinshajiang - or 'river of golden sand' as the upper reaches of the Yangtze are known. Second and third on the agency's list were two power stations being built at the $22bn Three Gorges Dam project on the central Yangtze - an underground 4,200 MW power plant and a 100 MW plant.
 
 The Three Gorges Dam has proved controversial in China - where more than half a million people have been relocated to make way for it - and abroad. It has drawn criticism from environmental groups and overseas human rights activists. The damming of the Upper Yangtze has also begun to attract criticism from environmentalists in China. In April 2004, central government officials ordered a halt to work on the nearby Nu River, which is part of a United Nations world heritage site, the Three Parallel Rivers site which covers the Yangtze, Mekong and Nu (also known as the Salween), according to the UK-published China Review. That move reportedly followed a protest from the Thai government about the downstream impact of the dams, and a critical documentary made by Chinese journalists. China's energy shortage influenced global prices for oil, coal and shipping last year.
llama3.2:1b: China has suspended 26 big power stations on environmental grounds due to incomplete assessments.
The suspension includes projects at the Three Gorges Dam, which has been deemed illegal due to lack of proper assessments.
Other affected projects include a petrochemicals plant and port in Fujian.
China's central government aims to control projects licensed by local officials and increase energy supplies for its booming economy.
llama3.2:3b: China has halted 30 construction projects on environmental grounds, including power stations at the Three Gorges Dam, citing failures in environmental assessments.
Some projects may be allowed to resume with proper permits, while others are likely to be cancelled.
The move comes as China struggles to address energy shortages, which forced many factories onto part-time working last year.
gemma2:2b: China has halted construction on 26 power projects due to environmental concerns, citing failure to complete proper environmental assessments.
Some projects may be allowed to resume with necessary permits, while others will be cancelled.
The move is part of a broader effort by the central government to control local official licensing and address the chronic energy shortage that has impacted factory operations in the country.
The largest project halted was the Xiluodi Dam, designed to generate 12,600 MW of electricity.
The Three Gorges Dam project itself, known for environmental controversy, is also among those affected.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Chinese government has suspended 26 power projects amid environmental concerns and criticism from environmental groups and human rights activists.
The Three Gorges Dam project is particularly controversial in China due to its relocation of nearly half a million people and the impact on the UK's UNESCO World Heritage site.
qwen2.5:1.5b: China has suspended 26 large power projects due to environmental concerns, including those at two Three Gorges Dam sites, amid energy shortages that led to blackouts in 24 provinces.
The move aims to crack down on local officials' overcapacity project licenses and control illegal construction projects.
qwen2.5:3b: China has suspended construction on 26 power projects, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to environmental concerns.
The move is seen as part of efforts to control local government-approved projects amidst increasing energy demands.
Some projects may be allowed to continue with permits, while others will be cancelled.
The largest suspension involves Xiluodi Dam, designed for 12,600 MW capacity on the Jinshajiang River.
Environmental and human rights groups have criticized the Three Gorges Dam project.
Construction on a dam near the Nu River, part of a UNESCO World Heritage site, was halted in April due to concerns about downstream impacts and environmental effects.
opencoder:1.5b: China suspended 26 power projects due to unforeseen environmental challenges.
The construction work on 26 big power stations including The Three Gorges Dam was halted as it did not meet environmental standards.
The move was a surprising event because the country struggled to increase energy supply for its booming economy.
In previous years, 24 provinces had suffered blackouts due to severe weather events.
The State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) reported that several projects failed due to non-compliance with environmental assessments.
One of the projects - a controversial dam at Yangtze's scenic upper reaches - stood tall in the list of approved construction projects.
Some of the projects included petrochemicals and ports.
The agency ordered 30 projects halted, but some were allowed to resume work.
Projects like Xiluodi Dam, which produces 12,600 MW of electricity, have been identified as potential issues.
The construction project involving a canal that generates 4,200 MW of electricity was also part of the list.
China's energy shortages are forcing many factories onto part-time working - last year, a 12.6% increase in generating capacity by China exceeded 440,700 MW (milliwatts) with the Xiluodi Dam project.
Last year, China increased its power plant generation capacity by 12.6%, or 440,700 MW (milliwatts).
This means that more than half a million people have been relocated to make way for the damming projects.
Environmental experts in China have also criticized the Three Gorges Dam's location in the center of the Yangtze River and Nu Parallel Rivers, suggesting its potential as an investment.
The global economic recession and climate change warning have contributed to higher energy prices, affecting global oil, coal, and shipping exports last year.
This has influenced global consumer behavior, leading to increased demands for jobs and driving a lack of public transportation.
smollm:1.7b: China suspends 26 power projects due to environmental concerns
deepseek-r1:1.5b: China has halted construction work on 26 power projects, including those at the Three Gorges Dam and Xiluodi Dam.
The Chinese State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) is concerned due to improper environmental assessments.
Some projects may restart with permits, while others are canceled, resulting in a total of 30 stops.
Key projects include the Three Gorges Dam for 12,600 MW of electricity and the Xiluodi project on the Jinshajiang River.
tinyllama:1.1b: China has suspended construction work on 26 big power stations, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, after environmental concerns were raised.
The move comes amid a struggle to increase energy supplies in China, which is facing chronic shortages due to overcapacity.
In December 2004, the central government ordered a halt to work on the nearby Nu River, which is part of an international World Heritage site known as "Three Parallel Rivers".
The decision followed protests from the Thai government about the potential downstream impact of the dam projects.
The construction of new power stations, including the Xiluoqiang project and Three Gorgets Dam, has been suspended, with further projects on hold pending the completion of assessments.
However, some projects, including a petrocemicals plant and port in Fujian, have been permitted to start work again after being halted earlier.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The suspension of 26 large power projects in China, including the construction of two at the Three Gorges Dam, was announced due to environmental concerns raised about their impact on the environment.
This move is a surprising development considering that China struggles to meet its energy demands and has been facing increased blackouts recently.
The suspension was ordered by the Chinese government, which stated that the projects had not properly assess the environmental impacts of their construction.
Some of the suspended projects included in this list include a port on Fujian's coastline and a new petrochemicals plant in Fuzhou.
The bulk of the list was made up of new power plants, which could be allowed to proceed with proper permits.
These actions are part of China's battle to control more than 30 large projects licensed by local officials.
The Three Gorges Dam project is a contentious topic in China, where over half a million people have been relocated for the sake of it.
The damming of the Yangtze River has also raised concerns about environmental impacts, which have led to criticism from environmental groups and international human rights activists.
The suspension of these projects may be another step in the fight against excessive energy production.
phi:2.7b: The text summarizes that China has ordered a halt to construction on 26 big power stations, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to environmental grounds.
This decision is surprising because China is struggling to increase its energy supplies, but it aims to improve the proper assessment of projects' environmental impact.
Some of these power plants may be allowed to start work again with proper permits, while others will be cancelled.

This move by the State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) represents another step in the central government's control over licensed projects and is an attempt to address issues related to energy shortages that forced many factories onto part-time working last year.
orca-mini:3b: China has ordered a halt to construction work on 26 big power stations, including the Three Gorges Dam, citing environmental concerns.
The move is surprising because China is struggling to increase energy supplies for its booming economy.
Some of the projects may be allowed to start work again with proper permits, but others would be cancelled.
The agency ordered 30 projects halted, including a petrochemicals plant and a port in Fujian.
The halt to construction follows previous crackdowns on projects argued there was overcapacity such as steel and cement.
The government has encouraged construction of new electricity generating capacity to solve chronic energy shortages that forced many factories onto part-time working last year.
hermes3:3b: China suspends 26 power projects, citing lack of proper environmental assessments; 2 at Three Gorges Dam included.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: China has suspended construction on 26 major power projects, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to insufficient environmental assessments.
The State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) said that the 26 projects failed to obtain proper approval for evaluating their impact on the environment.
Some of the projects may be allowed to start work again after obtaining the necessary permits, but others will be canceled altogether.
This move appears to be part of the central government's ongoing effort to control projects licensed by local officials.
The Three Gorges Dam project has faced criticism from environmental groups and overseas human rights activists due to its impact on the environment and the displacement of people living in the area.
China's energy shortage last year influenced global prices for oil, coal, and shipping.
chatgpt-4o-latest: China has suspended construction on 26 major power projects, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to environmental concerns.
The State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) stated that these projects had begun without proper environmental assessments, labeling them as illegal.
Some projects may resume with proper permits, while others will be canceled.
The move is notable as China faces energy shortages, with 24 provinces experiencing blackouts last year.
The largest halted project is the Xiluodi Dam, designed to generate 12,600 MW.
The Three Gorges Dam, already controversial for displacing over half a million people, has faced criticism from environmentalists and human rights activists.
The decision reflects the central government's efforts to regulate projects approved by local officials.
China's energy shortages have also impacted global oil, coal, and shipping prices.
stablelm2:1.6b: China has suspended construction work on several large power projects, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to environmental concerns.
The State Environmental Protection Agency criticized these projects for failing to conduct proper assessments of their impact on the environment.
Some projects may resume construction with proper permits, while others will be cancelled.
This move follows previous government crackdowns targeting overcapacity projects rather than those addressing energy shortages.
China aims to increase generating capacity and has already achieved a 6% increase in electricity generation, or 54 GW of installed capacity.
The biggest affected project was the Xiluodi Dam, designed to produce 80 GW of electricity, being halted due to environmental concerns.
granite3.1-dense:2b: China has temporarily halted construction on 26 large power projects, including two at the Three Gorges Dam, due to environmental concerns.

This decision is surprising given China's ongoing effort to meet energy demands for its growing economy, which led to blackouts in 24 provinces last year and necessitated a 12.6% increase in generating capacity in 2004.
The State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) stated that these projects lacked proper environmental assessments, characterizing their construction as "construction first, approval next."
Among the affected projects are notable ones like a petrochemicals plant and a port in Fujian, as well as extensions to existing power plants.
While some projects may resume with permits, 14 are set to be cancelled entirely.

This action is part of the central government's broader strategy to control projects approved by local officials, though previous crackdowns have focused on overcapacity in industries like steel and cement.
The Three Gorges Dam, a contentious project due to its environmental impact and displacement of over half a million people, stands out as the most significant project halted (12,600 MW).
Other notable projects on the list include two power stations at the controversial dam site.
The decision reflects China's increasing commitment to addressing environmental issues alongside its energy goals, which have influenced global commodity prices last year.
